field_edited_text.value:
Policy:

The City, State, and private seCtor
should work together to put vacant
and underutilized port, industrial
land to its highest and best use in
terms of taxes and jobs.

[ 4

Maryland Port Administration





There are also costs incurred by the
operation of railroads and marine terminals
which must be bourne by the City however
are not as obvious. Major port terminals
generate large volumes of truck traffic
which must travel over local streets and at
time through commercial and residential
areas. The cost for repairing streets and
bridges is the responsibility of the local
jurisdiction.

The City believes that both real and
hidden costs of State operated and leased
facilities must be calculated and addressed
by the appropriate State agency or user.

&

While the majority of land owned by
the State, railroads and the private sector is
in active, port related uses there are parcels
which are vacant or used only occassionally
for temporary storage. This underutilization
of land yields few jobs, often less than one
employee for every four acres. For every 50
acres of vacant or underutilized land the
potential is lost to create 750 jobs in an
intensive manufacturing use or 200 jobs as a
marine cargo facility.

Because land adjacent to the harbor is
so limited the development and marketing
efforts of the City, State and private sector
should be jointly utilized to attract indus-
tries or port operators which will yield the
highest level of employment possible.

Baltimore City fireboat at work

110
